text:
So I think we
recognized very quickly

that there were a
number of things
we could work on together.

And I think this
presented itself

as probably the
most logical-- is

to take traditional strengths
we have in the MBA and Master's

of science program and find
the kind of optimal fusion

of bringing the strengths
of management and technology
together.

You know, we were very
fortunate that the world

seemed to be moving in terms
of creating real demand
for this joint degree as well.

People who could have
this joint set of skills

of deep technical expertise, but
also great general management

together would be
able to do things
that the world really demanded.

And this seemed like a
great opportunity for us
to get going.

It really embodies the one
Harvard, boundary-less,
interdisciplinary approach.

We certainly in SEAS
really look outwards.

We look for the possibilities
to intersect with medicine,
with law, or with business.

But historically, we
haven't capitalized on that.

We haven't brought
those silos under sort

of common academic programs,
common research programs.

We've witnessed, really,
over the last decade,

where those walls have
been knocked down.

And now, we are truly working
together as a common faculty

to do curricular initiatives,
to pursue research agendas,

to build partnerships,
to build collegiality.

And so I think that's a
really exciting part of this.

If you think about the leaders
who have inspired the world's

imagination, many
of them end up being

people who were known for
some technology expertise

but then either formally
gained some business experience

or just learned
it along the way.

These are the leaders of
organizations from Amazon
to Google to Facebook.

My hope is that
our program will be

able to develop the next
generation of these leaders.

Certainly with
everybody believing

that there's a life science
revolution and the information

technology revolution
that is still underway.

And those are great
strengths at SEAS

and those are clearly gigantic
business opportunities.

I think the connection of
those two things, where there's

both enough areas
of overlap but also,

generally different
expertise, is

what excites me the
most about this program.

Not only is the excitement
great in those areas,
but it's going to accelerate.

The world's imagination
has been captured

by this one generation
of great companies

that were built
in Silicon Valley.

But there's no reason to
believe that another generation

of these companies
won't be built here.

I think there is
an ecosystem here
that's very conducive to that.

And you look at the complex mix
of universities, of hospitals,
of companies in close proximity.

And I think for
that reason, it's

conducive to a very different
kind of close collaborative
ecosystem.

It could make the ecosystem
work for everyone, in which we
will play a leadership role.

But everybody else would
also play a leadership role.

The whole could
be so much greater
than the sum of the parts.
